title: Malcolm Gladwell Can’t Tell if You Like His New Book
text:
In his new book, Malcolm Gladwell argues that we can’t tell when people are lying, we default to believing them and that a person’s outward behavior isn’t always a good barometer of what’s going on inside.

“Talking to Strangers: What We Should Know About the People We Don’t Know,” will be published Tuesday.To illustrate his point, Mr. Gladwell enlists Neville Chamberlain, the cast of “Friends” and Sandra Bland, whose story became a flashpoint in the Black Lives Matter movement. Ms. Bland apparently took her life in a Texas jail in 2015, three days after a routine traffic stop. The situation escalated after a police officer took issue with the fact that while in her car, Ms. Bland lighted a cigarette and refused to extinguish it.

The book provides fodder both for fans of Mr. Gladwell’s contrarian narratives and critics who say he cherry-picks anecdotes and states the obvious. The Journal spoke with him about talking to strangers and watching “Friends.” Edited excerpts:

You seem to be trying to prove something that reasonable people agree on—that we should give people the benefit of the doubt and that you can’t judge a book by its cover.

I think that’s true of a lot of my writing, that what I’m trying to do is give us more complete and convincing explanations for common sense positions. You know, I’m not arguing an outrageous position here, but I do think that we deviate from common sense a lot in the way that we make sense of others.

You wrote “The death of Sandra Bland is what happens when a society does not know how to talk to strangers.” Does that mean you don’t think her arrest was racially motivated?

I spend almost no time at all talking about race in this book, which does not mean that I think race isn’t a relevant consideration. On the contrary, I think race powerfully runs through many of these encounters, particularly that encounter. My issue with describing these encounters solely in racial terms is: What do you do next? Like, how do you fix it? Are you going to go and change the hearts of every police officer in America?

Some critics say you present contributing factors as causation. You write that the death of Sandra Bland is what happens when society doesn’t know how to talk to strangers—not that it’s due to many things and that this is a small part of it. Would you say that’s fair?

I would say that books are not term papers. If you write a term paper on the causes of the second World War, your professor, I think appropriately, wants you to be comprehensive. You can’t just say the second World War was about the economic aftermath of a bad settlement of the first World War. You’ve got to talk about Hitler, you’ve got to talk about ideology. But a book is not that. Books have a very different function. And sometimes, particularly in my books, what I’m trying to do is to shed light on ways of making sense of things that have not received appropriate attention in the past.

If we’re chronically misunderstanding the actions and intentions of strangers, should we also behave as if our own actions and intentions are being misunderstood?

Oh, yeah. When I talked about caution and humility, it applies not just to our attempts to make sense of others, but also to our understanding of how we ought to express ourselves, that we need to understand and keep in the back of our minds the notion that our behavior is not transparent.

Share Your Thoughts What do you think about some of the takeaways in Mr. Gladwell’s new book, such as a person’s outward behavior isn’t always a good barometer of what’s going on inside? Join the discussion below.

You wrote “We believe someone’s demeanor is a window into their soul” and that we think real life is like “Friends.” Have you ever met someone who believes that?

Sure. In fact, I think most people think that way. I mean, that’s not a feeling. There is a voluminous literature, for example, which goes back many, many years and encompasses a huge pile of research papers which look at what the attitudes of people in law enforcement are on the usefulness of facial expressions and demeanor in interpreting peoples’ truth or falsity. And what you discover is that among the people for whom this kind of question matters—cops interrogating people—they overwhelmingly think real life is like “Friends.”

But we know “Friends” is a caricature and that’s why we have clichés like “Don’t judge a book by its cover” and “You’ve got to walk a mile in someone’s shoes.”

Well, we have those clichés precisely because we don’t abide by them, right? We have the cliché “Don’t judge a book by its cover” because we are guilty of judging books by their cover. We remind our children to walk a mile in a man’s shoes before you judge them because we don’t walk a mile in people’s shoes, right? So, the mere fact that those clichés are so culturally prevalent ought to be proof of how routinely we deviate from them.
description: In ‘Talking to Strangers,’ the journalist and podcaster argues that behavior doesn’t always reflect a person’s real thoughts.
